item.title: New Research Absolves the Woman Blamed for a Dynasty’s Ruin
item.content:encoded: A Chinese king’s infatuation with a woman was seen as the reason that a golden age collapsed. Evidence suggests climate change and internal strife played bigger roles.

item.title: Department of Homeland Security Shuts Down, Though Essential Work Continues
item.content:encoded: Though funding for the department ran out early Saturday, officials said its essential functions would continue.

item.title: Casey Wasserman Will Sell Entertainment Agency Amid Epstein Files Fallout
item.content:encoded: Casey Wasserman, a Los Angeles entertainment executive and the head of the 2028 Olympic Games, has lost clients since his emails with Ghislaine Maxwell surfaced.

item.title: How China Built a Chip Industry, and Why It’s Still Not Enough
item.content:encoded: More than a decade into Beijing’s push for self sufficiency, Chinese firms are producing fewer, lower-performing chips than their foreign competitors.

item.title: How China Built a Chip Industry, and Why It’s Still Not Enough
item.content:encoded: More than a decade into Beijing’s push for self sufficiency, Chinese firms are producing fewer, lower-performing chips than their foreign competitors.

item.title: ’The Interview’: Gisèle Pelicot Shares Her Story
item.content:encoded: In her first interview with an American media outlet, Pelicot opens up about surviving years of secret abuse — and a trial that shocked the world.

item.title: Ramping Up Election Attacks, Trump Does Not Let Reality Get in His Way
item.content:encoded: President Trump increases his attacks when he fears an election loss. With midterm elections approaching, he has gone into overdrive as Republicans face potential losses.

item.title: Trump’s Actions Test the Fragile World of Air Travel
item.content:encoded: Last-minute announcements and abrupt changes by the Trump administration have caused confusion in an already strained U.S. aviation system.

item.title: Consultants Offered Epstein Access to Top N.Y. Democrats if He Donated
item.content:encoded: Dynamic SRG repeatedly, and apparently unsuccessfully, asked the sex offender Jeffrey Epstein to donate to House races, Justice Department records show.

item.title: ICE Agents Menaced Minnesota Protesters at Their Homes, Filings Say
item.content:encoded: Protesters in Minneapolis and St. Paul said in sworn statements that they were singled out by agents who demonstrated that they knew where they lived.

item.title: Dutch Prosecutors Fine Louis Vuitton Netherlands in Money Laundering Case
item.content:encoded: The Dutch subsidiary of the luxury brand agreed to pay a nearly $600,000 settlement in a money laundering and terrorism financing case.

item.title: Trump Administration Tells Judge It Will Release Gateway Funding
item.content:encoded: Payments for the $16 billion rail tunnel between New York City and New Jersey had been suspended for more than four months.

item.title: Florida Couple Arrested After Pickleball Match Turns Into a Brawl
item.content:encoded: The couple, who were banned for life from a country club in Port Orange, Fla., face felony battery charges after the fight, which involved 20 people, the authorities said.

item.title: Measles Outbreak Hits Ave Maria University in Florida
item.content:encoded: More than 40 people have fallen ill at Ave Maria University, raising fears that college campuses may soon experience more measles outbreaks.

item.title: Who Is Jeremy Carl, Trump’s Nominee to Lead the State Department?
item.content:encoded: Jeremy Carl, President Trump’s nominee to lead the State Department’s outreach to international organizations, had a rough confirmation hearing, but he stood by his views on “whiteness.”

item.title: Homeland Security Demands Social Media Sites Reveal Names Behind Anti-ICE Posts
item.content:encoded: The department has sent Google, Meta and other companies hundreds of subpoenas for information on accounts that track or comment on Immigration and Customs Enforcement, officials and tech workers said.

item.title: Homeland Security Demands Social Media Sites Reveal Names Behind Anti-ICE Posts
item.content:encoded: The department has sent Google, Meta and other companies hundreds of subpoenas for information on accounts that track or comment on Immigration and Customs Enforcement, officials and tech workers said.

item.title: Venezuela’s Natural Gas, Not Oil, Might Be a Big Early Prize
item.content:encoded: The South American country has natural gas that could be extracted and exported quickly, but U.S. sanctions, which are now being eased, have stymied development.

item.title: The Mutually Beneficial Ties Between Jeffrey Epstein and Thorbjorn Jagland
item.content:encoded: Thorbjorn Jagland, a former prime minister of Norway who led the Nobel Committee, promised influence, and the disgraced financier had gifts to give, new emails show.

item.title: After a Harrowing Water Rescue, Baby Is Delivered on Mother’s Birthday
item.content:encoded: Shedly Apollon was on her way to a prenatal massage when she started to feel faint while on the road. Her car veered off the highway and into a lake.

item.title: At Munich Summit, European Leaders Agree With Trump: The Old World Order Is Over
item.content:encoded: At the Munich Security Conference, U.S. officials softened their tone but not their message: Europe should pay its own way. European leaders increasingly agree.

item.title: White House Sees Win After 2 Strong Economic Reports
item.content:encoded: Solid jobs data and a soft inflation reading for January are welcome news for President Trump. But the bigger economic picture is less encouraging.

item.title: White House Sees Win After 2 Strong Economic Reports
item.content:encoded: Solid jobs data and a soft inflation reading for January are welcome news for President Trump. But the bigger economic picture is less encouraging.

item.title: Prosecutor Seeks Dismissal of Charges Against Man Shot by ICE
item.content:encoded: A judge dropped charges against the immigrant and another man after the top federal prosecutor in Minnesota said new evidence was not consistent with the agents’ testimony.

item.title: RFK Jr. Allies Target States to Overturn Vaccine Mandates for Schools
item.content:encoded: Proponents of vaccines warn that the efforts will further dismantle the immunization infrastructure and lead to more outbreaks of disease.

item.title: RFK Jr. Allies Target States to Overturn Vaccine Mandates for Schools
item.content:encoded: Proponents of vaccines warn that the efforts will further dismantle the immunization infrastructure and lead to more outbreaks of disease.

item.title: Au Pair Juliana Peres Magalhães Sentenced to 10 Years in Banfield Double Murder Case
item.content:encoded: Juliana Peres Magalhães, 25, had cooperated with prosecutors, who sought a lenient sentence. But the judge said the woman, who pleaded guilty to manslaughter, merited the state maximum.

item.title: It’s a Grocery Store, but Selling Food Isn’t the Point
item.content:encoded: Happier Grocery in New York is an entry point for people seeking a community built on inside knowledge. It’s not the only high-end grocer doing this.

item.title: Christie’s to Auction 3 of Agnes Gund’s Art Jewels
item.content:encoded: A Rothko, a Twombly and a Surrealist box with a Medici princess by Joseph Cornell are estimated to sell for $145 million.

item.title: U.S. Inflation Eased at Start of the Year
item.content:encoded: The Consumer Price Index fell in January to 2.4 percent from 2.7 percent a month

item.title: One Last Chat With David Brooks
item.content:encoded: Before leaving The Times after 22 years, David Brooks responds to readers’ questions.

item.title: Goldman Sachs General Counsel Kathryn Ruemmler Resigns Over Epstein Ties
item.content:encoded: Kathryn Ruemmler, a former top Obama administration lawyer, is out at Goldman Sachs after emails showed a friendship with the sex offender Jeffrey Epstein spanning many years.

item.title: Bessent Pushes Senate on Fed Confirmation Amid Backlash Over Criminal Inquiry
item.content:encoded: President Trump’s effort to get Kevin M. Warsh confirmed as the next Federal Reserve chair has been complicated by a criminal investigation into Jerome H. Powell.

item.title: Trying to Cut Costs? Start With Your Phone, Internet and Streaming Bills.
item.content:encoded: It’s cold outside — and a fine time to look over your bills and see where you can save.

item.title: Crises Everywhere, but the Markets Don’t Seem to Mind
item.content:encoded: Stocks have prospered while the world has plunged into disorder, an economist says. “Keep calm and carry on” may be the best investors can do.

item.title: Crises Everywhere, but the Markets Don’t Seem to Mind
item.content:encoded: Stocks have prospered while the world has plunged into disorder, an economist says. “Keep calm and carry on” may be the best investors can do.

item.title: More Epstein Fallout for Goldman Sachs, DP World and Beyond
item.content:encoded: The Wall Street giant’s top lawyer, whose ties to Jeffrey Epstein had raised questions at the firm, has resigned. Other corporate leaders are also facing blowback.

item.title: The Hidden Number Driving U.S. Job Growth
item.content:encoded: After a year of just 181,000 new jobs, January’s 131,000 increase in the U.S. workforce was surprisingly positive. Ben Casselman, The New York Times’ chief economic correspondent, explains the numbers.

item.title: Another Government Shutdown? Here’s What Travelers Should Know.
item.content:encoded: It was not immediately clear whether passengers would face delays at airport security checkpoints in the coming days if a government shutdown does occur.

item.title: Meta Plans to Add Facial Recognition Technology to Its Smart Glasses
item.content:encoded: In an internal memo last year, Meta said the political tumult in the United States would distract critics from the feature’s release.

item.title: Conspiracy Theories Only Flourish With More Epstein Evidence
item.content:encoded: The dump of millions of documents has fueled a new wave of speculation, A.I.-generated hoaxes and foreign disinformation.

item.title: Crab Heist Puts Spotlight on Surge of Cargo Thefts
item.content:encoded: Stolen food and beverages, which are easier to offload than costly electronics, are driving an overall spike in cargo crimes, truckers, insurers and other experts say.

item.title: Amtrak’s Largest Train Revamp in 55 Years Is Coming Soon
item.content:encoded: Step inside the sprawling factory in California where the largest fleet replacement in Amtrak’s 55-year history is coming together piece by piece.

item.title: Iran Turns to Digital Surveillance Tools to Track Down Protesters
item.content:encoded: As Iranian authorities restore some online services after crushing antigovernment demonstrations, they are using a technological dragnet to target attendees of the protests.

item.title: States Say No Thanks to Trump Tax Cuts, Drawing Republican Fire
item.content:encoded: State income taxes often reflect federal policies, but Washington, D.C. and some states have taken steps to keep the latest Republican changes out of their tax codes.

item.title: South Korean Court Rules Against Women in LG Inheritance Lawsuit
item.content:encoded: The widow and two daughters of LG’s former chairman sought to invalidate an inheritance agreement, claiming they were deceived into forfeiting their rightful inheritance.

item.title: El Paso Incident Highlights Gaps in America’s Drone Defense Industry
item.content:encoded: The U.S. has spent billions of dollars developing counter-drone technology, but much of it needs more testing in the real world.

item.title: Flexibility and Rising Costs Are Keeping Mothers at Work
item.content:encoded: Labor force participation for women with small children continues to float above prepandemic levels, thanks to flexible work setups — and rising costs.

item.title: Europe Worries Trump Poses Threat to Its Financial and Tech Sovereignty
item.content:encoded: European leaders have been compelled to address the possibility of once-remote risks to the financial networks and technology that undergird their economies.

item.title: Laid-Off Battery Plant Workers Pin Blame on Ford, not Trump, for Lost Jobs
item.content:encoded: Ford Motor shut down a battery factory and laid off 1,600 workers after President Trump and Republicans gutted government support for electric vehicles.

item.title: To Stay in Her Home, She Let In an A.I. Robot
item.content:encoded: At 85, Jan Worrell lived alone on a remote corner of the Washington coast. Could ElliQ become her companion?

item.title: Americans Are Paying the Bill for Tariffs, Despite Trump’s Claims
item.content:encoded: Research from the New York Fed confirms that U.S. companies and consumers are bearing tariff costs, despite the president’s assertions otherwise.

item.title: Olympic Figure Skaters Are on Thin Ice Over Music Copyright Rules
item.content:encoded: Some Olympic athletes have found themselves caught up in controversies over musical choices before and during one of the biggest competitions of their careers.

item.title: The Giant Super PACs Fighting Over A.I. Safety
item.content:encoded: Anthropic is pouring millions of dollars into a political action committee that will most likely face off against OpenAI.

item.title: How ‘The Traitors’ Builds Its Perfect Reality TV Cast
item.content:encoded: The casting executives behind the Emmy-winning reality competition reveal how they create a mad mix of modern celebrity.

item.title: Ford Will Make a Play for a Different Battery Market
item.content:encoded: The company, long focused on cars and trucks, plans to begin manufacturing large batteries used by utilities, data centers, other businesses and homeowners.

item.title: New Method Can Find Hidden Eggs to Aid in Fertility Treatment
item.content:encoded: A study reported that the conventional method of searching follicular fluid didn’t find all the eggs. The new technology found extra eggs more than half the time.

item.title: Bans on Many CBD Products Loom This Year
item.content:encoded: A federal law taking effect in November severely limits the amount of THC, the euphoric cannabis compound, allowed in over-the-counter items. Many groups are fighting back.

item.title: Maybe America Needs Some New Cities
item.content:encoded: It sounds a bit kooky to promise a whole city from scratch. But it has been done before — and might just help solve the housing crisis.

item.title: India’s Prime Minister Faces Blowback Over Trade Deal With Trump to Lower Tariffs
item.content:encoded: Prime Minister Narendra Modi won a big reduction of sky-high tariffs, but critics say he undermined Indian sovereignty and undercut the nation’s farmers.

item.title: Sales at McDonald’s Rise, Driven by Value Meals and Grinch Socks
item.content:encoded: Profits were up as the fast-food giant focused on price-conscious customers. But the company said it would cut back on financial support for franchisees.

item.title: U.S. Health Officials Defend Rejection of Moderna’s Flu Vaccine
item.content:encoded: The F.D.A.’s refusal to examine the company’s mRNA shot drew widespread criticism from doctors and was divisive within the agency.

item.title: Kalshi and Polymarket Create New Competition for Professional Economists
item.content:encoded: Economists have noticed that betting markets like Kalshi and Polymarket are pretty good at predicting not just political events but economic data, too.

item.title: New Kraft Heinz CEO Says Food Company Won’t Split, for Now
item.content:encoded: The company’s new C.E.O. said he saw opportunities to fix and grow the food giant — and cut prices for consumers.

item.title: Lower Unemployment Rate Supports Longer Pause for Fed
item.content:encoded: January’s jobs data, released on Wednesday, bolstered expectations that the Federal Reserve will hold interest rates steady for longer than previously expected.

item.title: Job Growth Was Overstated, New Data Shows
item.content:encoded: Annual revisions show that employers added far fewer jobs in 2024 and 2025 than previously estimated.

item.title: Five Surprising Moments With Anna Wintour and Chloe Malle, U.S. Vogue’s New Top Editor
item.content:encoded: What is Ms. Wintour’s alternative career path? Who does Ms. Malle hope to rub elbows with at the Met Gala? More from our interview with American Vogue’s past and present.

item.title: What Executives Are Saying About the ‘K-Shaped’ Economy
item.content:encoded: Leaders across industries from airlines to packaged foods have said a growing divide between lower-income and wealthy consumers is changing their businesses.

item.title: Federal Debt to Hit Record Levels, Budget Office Warns
item.content:encoded: President Trump has reshaped the country’s economic policies, but the outlook for the budget remains dire.

item.title: What to know about the better-than-expected report.
After a Year of Sluggish Hiring, 2026 Is Off to a Stronger Start
item.content:encoded: The economy added substantially more jobs than expected last month, as more people entered the labor force and wages grew.

item.title: Wall St. and Washington Brace for a Big Jobs Report
item.content:encoded: A hiring slowdown and fears about artificial intelligence have investors on edge, and some in the Trump administration on the defensive.

item.title: Trump plans to nominate a ‘data nerd’ to lead Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The One Child Policy’s Legacy: A Surplus of Single Men
item.content:encoded: A decade after the end of the one-child policy, China has over 30 million so-called surplus men. Can this dating boot camp help them find love?
